reviewText:
I bought this game when it first came out in the year 2008. It cost 19.90 USD then, and I got it at full price (there wasn't so much discounts on steam back then). Was I skeptical? Yes, I was. I was skeptical because the concept of this game seems simplistic. Of course, this game has convinced me after a while that I have made the correct investment by paying for it at full price.

What this game appears to be is that it converts sound files (music files such as .mp3 ones) into a linear ongoing track of some sort. You get to control a small little car-like vehicle, though the only movement you can perform are sideways. The speed of your little car-like thingy is determined by the pace of your music, which is represented by the colour of the track you are riding on. I won't go into detail on the blocks and game play, but that's basically it.

In short, this game lets you ride the music.

And yes, you can ride on almost any musical file you've loaded into the game, and this is what make this game great and worthwhile.

There is one particular game mode which I like - mono. It's basically a no-brainer where you simply hit the colour blocks and avoid the grey blocks as you move forward along the track. It's a splendid mode to relax yourself with, especially after a day of tiring work when all you want is some of your favourite music and soothing gameplay.

I got it at 2008, and it's 2014 now. Years passed, and many parts of my life have changed. Still, what remained the same is that, after all these years, I will still give new music a run or two here, in audiosurf.

Oh and did I mention that I am still getting e-mails from audiosurf's scoreboard saying that I have been dethroned? Yeah, it's nice to see these e-mails amidst all those work mails and all.

You are staring at your steam games. There is a big list of around 70-80 games. You bought them couple games on the steam summer sale, but they have become bland, boring, and gray. You see you have an extra ten dollars left over from the last game you bought, which for you has also become boring quite quick. You scroll through steam and something catches you eye... Audiosurf. This, is just as I was with Audiosurf, Bored of all my boring war games, the idea was old, and I needed something new. When I got audiosurf, I played the sample song,but thet quickely realized you can play custom music. Me, being a music person had a lot of music downloaded, but others may have to buy a few tracks and albums. I played everything, ranging from Skrillex to Nirvana to The Beatles, but this game can be played with virtually any game. This colorful cheap game was a new expirience to me, the gameplay was like nothing I have ever played before. With the charactor moving fastley dodging some colors and collecting others, making combos, passing song, it was extraodinary.

Audiosurf has many charactors, each with different powerups. Some will scramble colors, others may avoid certain colors or jump colors. The most uniques charactor (and my favorite) Is Ninja mono (With ironman Mode on). It increases speed and difficulty, and all blocks are the same, but you must avoid gray blocks. But some others may prefer different charactors, I enjoy the ride, but some may go for points and records.

Overall this Casual Music/Rythem Game has had me play for days and is quite addicting, but like everygame it has its flaws, it may have beutiful art and interesting gameplay, but after the first few days, you will only play it on days when you have almost nothing to do. Other than that this game is amazing. If you want a cheap game that will give you something to do and you love music, buy this game.

reviewText:
Party on down in your block collecting color rocket!

No, that's not dirty talk, it's just time for Irreverend Opinions to go virtually clubbing in Audiosurf.

---

The Blurb
Audiosurf is a unique game, in that it aims for a particular niche, and hits it almost dead-on.  You are a tiny ship that needs to collect colorful tiles for points as you fly down a raceway that is shaped according to the music you are flying to! Your ship increases and decreases in speed according to the pace of the music, and in general you need to avoid the grey blocks that don't correspond to your music - or you lose points. Highest points climbs the scoreboard!

The Good
Within the game, you can make use of a variety of streamed music for free, or import your own from your music list. For the most part, the graphics are clear (if a little seizure-inducing), and both the track and your ship's speed correspond to the music well for the majority of the time. There's a variety of game modes to allow you to challenge yourself.

The Bad
As mentioned, the game's graphics are pretty simple, and with the flashing colors and vibrant lights, if there is a game to cause epileptic seizures, this is definitely one.

For some unknown reason, the game doesn't always pick up a song's tempo or variance for the track and/or speed - which can lead to breakneck races through otherwise relaxing songs, or slow and sleep-inducing cruises while breakneck music violently plays in the background.

The game almost forces itself into fullscreen mode, though it really doesn't need it, and you have to edit an .ini file to avoid that.

Linux users using older machines may find their WINE driver-interpretation does not line up with the in-game text, leading to corrupted password input.

The Ugly
Not really anything. Audiosurf tries to be a music-focused racing game, and pulls it off with panache.

Suggestions
Can't think of much that isn't already covered in the sister game, Audiosurf 2.

The Summary
Musical racing game that seeks to work within it's niche and keep there.  The result?  It works it like it owns it.  9/10

Re-written because it was in need of a better review. Now with an extra paragraph.

Audiosurf is simply one of the most fantastic indie games to hit the market. This is for the simple reason that you can insert your own songs into the game. Sure, the options are limited to MP3s, but if you have a large collection of them then why not?

Every song you feed into the game is unique. A random track is generated based on the music and you collect blocks with your craft, attempting to make matches that make you gain the most points. There are a great variety of game modes to choose from (with some requiring more skill than others), and the fact that you can put any song into the game means that your potential replayability is only limited by the size of your library.

This isn't Guitar Hero's poor cousin. It is its equal. The various colours at times make you feel like you're having an acid trip. And, to be frank, I never got around to liking the Guitar Hero controller. It was really too awkward.

When to buy: It's okay to get this full price, but the Humble Store and Steam have recently had pretty sick discounts - 1 USD! Try to wait for those!

9.5/10

reviewText:
Audiosurf is a rhythm game in where you control one of various ships and try to collect blocks of the same color to make them match. You move across three lanes and blocks will be added to your inventory at the bottom of the screen on the lane that you collected it from. One of the neatest features of this game is that it allows you to play your own music and the game changes depending on the type of song you played. Song genres like heavy metal will be fast and frantic, throwing blocks at you to the rhythm of the music while slower paced genres like Country will be much slower and laid-back. It is recommended to start off with slower paced songs until you understand the game. If you don't have any music of your own Audiosurf does come with the Orange Box soundtrack that includes the songs from the Half Life series, Portal and Team Fortress 2. A cool little detail in the â€œStill Aliveâ€ song of Portal is that your ship will be Chellâ€™s Portal Gun. It's not a collection of music that will hold your attention for long so it may be best to have some music you like on your PC before playing.

You just find the songs you want to play in your music folder and the level will be built on its own. The rhythm and speed of the gameplay is nearly always spot on to whatever song you are playing. The gameplay changes slightly from the different characters you can choose from. One has the ability to hold a block and add it to a lane of his choice while another can delete all colored blocks of the next type you pick up. They are very minor differences between them and it will come down to preference to choose the one you like the most. A character named Mono is the only one that plays far differently and makes all the blocks in the game the same color but you must avoid the gray colorless blocks. I found this character to be the most fun to play as it is more reaction based than strategy based so you can enjoy the song a lot more while still being challenged. There are also two modes where you just listen to the music with no consequences. One is Freeride which you can just drive around in without worrying about blocks and the other is called Visualizer has you just staring at the screen and the trippy colors.

The environments are very weird and make no sense though they are colorful and you can't help but stare at the weird floating blocks at times. You can change the backgrounds colors and add some screen effects like Negative colors and Paint to miss around with the look of the game. If the sound effects of picking up blocks annoys you and makes your song sound weird you can change it or simply turn sound effects off all together. Collecting enough wrong colored blocks and filling up your inventories lane will cause you to malfunction for a bit and be able to collect any more blocks for a short time. No matter how many times you overfill your inventory there is no losing in this game so the main motivation is to compete on the leaderboards. Unfortunately you have to make an Audiosurf account and give out your email address to be able to post your scores. This game is very old and people have gotten extremely high scores on any song even remotely popular so it can be very hard to compete so having friends that also play this game makes for a far more fun experience if you care about showing off scores.

It is not all about collecting blocks as you may want to avoid some blocks near the end of the song to get the Clean Finish bonus that rewards you with 25% of your total score. That is when the minimap that displays the entire level comes in handy as you always know how close to ending the song is or when it is about to get intense from a downward drop in the graph. You also get rewarded for avoiding all the gray blocks as Mono so it is wise to remember that it can be far better to let a block go and try to get the hefty bonuses. It gives the game some depth to the game but for those of use that don't really care much about the score it is still fun to play a level made by your choice of song. There is something oddly addicting to jamming out to your favorite songs while collecting colored blocks in a trippy environment. Tons of characters with my personal favorite being Mono, lots of customization and even multiple graphics settings for those with lower end PCs. Never experienced any stutters, crashes or other glitches, just awesome music and tons of fun. Would definitely recommend this game to anyone with music on their computer.

The BPM/intensity detection is a bit flaky on some types of music, and the randomness makes any competitiveness of the game somewhat meaningless. What would happen if you combined Racing gameplay, Arcade action, and Music into one game? You get Audiosurf.

As far as music-based games go, usually they are very limited. You have your Guitar Heroes and Rock Bands, and then you have your Rocksmiths; however, there is a game that falls into none of those categories, Audiosurf.

Audiosurf is a rhythm-based game, that plays similar to multiple game genres. It has the feel of a racing game, the gameplay of an arcade game, and of course the music. Unlike Guitar Hero or those kinds of games, you are not limited to the songs you can play, you can play any song that is on your PC. Instead of a pre-determined setlist, I can have my pick. How it works is that the game generates a different track for each and every song you pick to play from your computer, so there is endless replay value as long as you have an extensive library of music like I do.

There are various game modes and difficulty levels you can play, Casual, Pro, and Elite are each of the difficulties. Game modes include:

Mono: In Mono you only have to collect one kind of block unlike other modes, you may think this as being too easy, but let me tell you, playing on harder difficulties or intricate songs, it can get really intense. You have to avoid all of the grey blocks in Mono mode, but on harder difficulties the grey blocks will be the main object on the screen.

Pointman: With Pointman you have to match multiple colored blocks, more or less depending on the difficulty. You have the power here to pick up blocks and place them in different spots or pick up a powerup and wait for the perfect time to use it. This adds a lot of strategy to a seemingly casual game.

Vegas: This is another favorite mode of mine. With Vegas, you have the power to randomly generate powerups and shuffle the board so you can get matches and avoid overfilling.

Eraser: This mode allows you to erase a certain type of block from your board. This, like Pointman adds a great deal of strategy to the game.

Pusher: This mode lets you push blocks to another side to use for later. Another very strategic mode.

Double Vision: This is the amazing multiplayer, It's much like the modes other then Mono, except that you don't have the powers. I have had so much fun with this co-op multiplayer.

The high score system adds in a healthy dose of competition, and usually even on less popular songs there will be some sort of competition waiting. So even if you run out of songs to play, you'll still be able to try and master the songs you've played.

Audiosurf is more then worth the 10 bucks it costs on Steam, and is a wonderful game that I'm sure you'll keep coming back to, Right up in the top 10 of my favorite PC games of all time. To be honest, there are no flaws in this game from what I can tell. Certainly a game worthy of more notice.

Graphics: 7/10

There's leaderboards per song, per difficulty, and even split into friends, nearby, and global. However as I play a lot of downloaded songs from youtube, or songs no one has except for a select few, I don't get ot participate in the whole leaderboard thing except with the built in tracks.

Overall: 8/10
The game has been around but the formula isn't old, I enjoy this game a lot and continue to do so, this game wasn't made by some big shot team so don't forget that.

AudioSurf is the first game I ever owned on Steam. In fact I owned it long before I really got into buying and playing games on Steam. But is it good? In a word, absolutely.

AudioSurf is one of the only games I can think of that offers truly unlimited replayability. The only limit is on the extent of your own personal music library and how much you like a particular song. It's simply really. You choose a song, the game analyzes it, and it creates a colorful and vibrant race course based on the tempo and beat of the song. You race down this course, all the while collecting colored blocks based on your chosen character, and then at the end, you get a score. Every song has a leaderboard that you can compete with others on.

The characters are spread out among three difficulties and range from simply matching colors to collect points, to dodging grey blocks and picking up colored ones, to the ability to shuffle and erase certain blocks, and more. reviewText: AudioSurf gameplay is fairly simple: get the colored blocks, avoid some other blocks, try to make them match. There's a few variations that basically change how you get and arrange the blocks, but the basis is always the same. That would make it a pretty standard puzzle game if it was its only aspect, though.\n\nWhat sets AudioSurf apart is the ability to import any kind of music and literally play it. Not just as a background music, but as the layout for the whole level. Elevation and speed, as well as the arrangement, frequency and colors of the blocks are all determined by the music. While a fair amount of games on Steam boast this ability, very few are capable to produce a level that feels unique and actually entirely determined by the music you import. As such, AudioSurf's tagline, Ride your music"
